No, that is not correct.  Each test runs in its own instance of TestCase so
placing test fixture code in the constructor will not make any difference.
(In a document and presentation I created for work, I have some potential
reasonS why setUp() exists at all).   For example,

  D:\junit\junitexamples\wwsdc>java junit.textui.TestRunner
EachTestOwnObject
  .
  setUp called
  test_underScore1 called
         in number 1 instance of class EachTestOwnObject
  tearDown called
  .
  setUp called
  test_underScore2 called
         in number 2 instance of class EachTestOwnObject
  tearDown called

  Time: 0.016

  OK (2 tests)


  So you do need to use the junit.extensions.TestSetup decorator.  Here is
an template that I hope
  might help

  public class TestSetupDecorator extends TestSetup
  {
     TestSetupDecorator(Test test){ super(test);}

     protected void setUp(){
         /* create resources or call static initialization
             methods of your test class */
     }

     protected void tearDown(){
         //free resources
     }
  }

  In your  child of TestCase,

  public static Test suite(){

     //Wrap your TestSuite in the decorator
         return new TestSetupDecorator(new
             TestSuite(
                 UserTestSetupDecorator.class));
  }


  Voila, you will get,

  D:\junit\junitexamples\wwsdc>java UserTestSetupDecorator

  TestSetupDecorator::setUp() called
  .
  setUp called
  test_underScore1
  tearDown called
  .
  setUp called
  test_underScore2
  tearDown called

  TestSetupDecorator::tearDown() called

  OK (2 tests)

  I hope this is sufficently clear- it's 5:OOam in morning but I can't
sleep
due to jet lag from travelling in Europe.  If not I will try to help more.
